In order to maintain [Dollar token](https://github.com/ubiquity/ubiquity-dollar/blob/0a230f977ad91bbfb01dd28bc1d2ea77faed5237/packages/contracts/src/dollar/core/UbiquityDollarToken.sol) USD peg [LibUbiquityPool](https://github.com/ubiquity/ubiquity-dollar/blob/0a230f977ad91bbfb01dd28bc1d2ea77faed5237/packages/contracts/src/dollar/libraries/LibUbiquityPool.sol) provides the following arbitrage mechanic:
1. If Dollar token USD price >1$ (on a secondary market) then arbitragers are incentivised to 
a) Mint 1 Dollar token for 1 USD of collateral in the [LibUbiquityPool](https://github.com/ubiquity/ubiquity-dollar/blob/0a230f977ad91bbfb01dd28bc1d2ea77faed5237/packages/contracts/src/dollar/libraries/LibUbiquityPool.sol)
b) Sell 1 Dollar token on a secondary market
2. On the contrary, If Dollar token USD price <1$ (on a secondary market) then arbitragers are incentivised to:
a) Buy cheap Dollar token on a secondary market
b) Redeem Dollar token for collateral worth 1 USD in the [LibUbiquityPool](https://github.com/ubiquity/ubiquity-dollar/blob/0a230f977ad91bbfb01dd28bc1d2ea77faed5237/packages/contracts/src/dollar/libraries/LibUbiquityPool.sol)

On early project stage any large swap may affect the Dollar token price greatly and the pool (where the swap occurred) may remain unbalanced for a long time which in turn depegs the Dollar token.

As a part of this issue we should create an arbitrage bot (i.e. `nodejs` app) which could be run on VPS or any suitable PAAS (heroku, cloudflare, etc...) to catch arbitrage opportunities in order to keep the Dollar token USD pegged on early project stage.

What should be done:
1. Create a new `nodejs` app that will catch arbitrage opportunities for the Dollar token
2. Add unit tests for basic functionality
3. Prepare a clear README of how to run the bot

Notes:
- It makes sense to create the arbitrage bot in a separate repository.
- Deployed contract addresses (mainnet): [here](https://github.com/ubiquity/ubiquity-dollar/blob/0a230f977ad91bbfb01dd28bc1d2ea77faed5237/packages/contracts/broadcast/Deploy001_Diamond_Dollar_Governance.s.sol/1/run-latest.json)

Adding collateral enabled checks for redemption collections might make users uncapable of redeming their funds.

[MEDIUM] - Adding collateral enabled checks for redemption collections might make users uncapable of redeming their funds.

This PR is intended to fix [the bug described in this Sherlock issue](https://github.com/sherlock-audit/2023-12-ubiquity-judging/issues/29). However, the Sherlock report is actually wrong and the vulnerability described must not be considered as an issue in the first place, so the collateralEnabled check should not be added on collecting redemptions.

Enabling/disabling collaterals allows the protocol to add or remove supported collaterals, not to be used under uncertain situations, such as a hack. In such type of situations, the `isRedeemPaused` check can be enabled to prevent users from redeeming if something wrong is currently  happening.

The problem with adding the `collateralEnabled` check here is that if Ubiquity decides to disable a collateral in the future, some redemptions might be already queued, so users won't be able to withdraw their funds.


Recommendation: Remove the `collateralEnabled` check for collecting redemptions.

Wrong consideration of number of blocks in `blockCountInAWeek`

## Issue Title
Wrong consideration of number of blocks in `blockCountInAWeek`

## Issue severity
Medium

## Vulnerability details

`DiamondInit.init()` contract is used to initializes a diamond with user defined state variables. The issue is the number of blocks considered in `blockCountInAWeek` is incorrect which will break the core intended design of contracts functionalities.

```Solidity
File: src/dollar/upgradeInitializers/DiamondInit.sol

        ls.blockCountInAWeek = 45361;
```

Affected code location: [check here](https://github.com/sherlock-audit/2023-12-ubiquity/blob/d9c39e8dfd5601e7e8db2e4b3390e7d8dff42a8e/ubiquity-dollar/packages/contracts/src/dollar/upgradeInitializers/DiamondInit.sol#L74)

The number of seconds in one week is `6,04,800` seconds and while calculating the `blockCountInAWeek`, the blocks formation period is considered to be `13.3` seconds. It is to be noted that Ethereum Proof of Work is deprecated and merged with Proof of stake which has different block formation period. It is explained as below,

1) During of Ethereum, Proof of work 13 to 16 seconds was an average block formation time before Ethereum merge i.e before september, 2022 and `13.3` seconds is considered in current implementation.

**BEFORE merge Ethereum block time reference with chart: 
![before merge](https://github.com/0xRizwan/Audit-snippets/assets/112799398/38f8b5b6-c62e-4dc7-8353-0c5a0154f231)

**However, Ethereum block formation happens on every 12 seconds and it is confirmed from below sources,**
[Ethereum official Reference-01](https://ethereum.org/en/developers/docs/blocks/#:~:text=In%20Ethereum%2C%20time%20is%20divided,the%20block%20time%20is%2012s)
[chainstack Reference-02](https://chainstack.com/protocols/ethereum/#Performance)
[ycharts Reference-03](https://ycharts.com/indicators/ethereum_average_block_time)

**AFTER merge Ethereum block time reference with chart: 

![Post merge](https://github.com/0xRizwan/Audit-snippets/assets/112799398/7050c8fc-8962-47ab-a06e-e3f0aa6c913f)


To see the actual difference, 

With current implementation: 

```Solidity
Total seconds in one week = 6,04,800
Considered Ethereum block formation period in second in current implementation = 13.33 approx
Therefore, ls.blockCountInAWeek = 45361;
```

With Ethereum Proof of stake,

```Solidity
Total seconds in one week = 6,04,800
Proposed Ethereum block formation period in second  = 12 approx
Therefore, ls.blockCountInAWeek = 50400;
```

The difference = 50400 - 45361 = 5039 = 17 hours approx.

This much time difference will affect wherever `blockCountInAWeek` variable used in contracts which will cause unexpected design failure. 

In `LibStaking.sol`, In `deposit()` function, To calculate the `_endBlock`, `blockCountInAWeek` variable is used,

```solidity

    function deposit(
        uint256 _lpsAmount,
        uint256 _weeks
    ) internal returns (uint256 _id) {


    . . . some code

        // calculate end locking period block number
        uint256 _endBlock = block.number + _weeks * ss.blockCountInAWeek;


    . . . some code
```

Similarly, in functions like `addLiquidity()`, 

```solidity

    function addLiquidity(
        uint256 _amount,
        uint256 _id,
        uint256 _weeks
    ) internal {

    . . . some code

        stake.endBlock = block.number + _weeks * ss.blockCountInAWeek;

    . . . some code

```

The end block calculation is getting delayed by 17 hours approx. which is loss of time of users in both of these functions due to incorrect calculations.

## Recommended Mitigation Steps
Consider 12 seconds block formation period.


```diff

-        ls.blockCountInAWeek = 45361;
+        ls.blockCountInAWeek = 50400;
```

Governance Token emissions to `ubq.eth` new strategy

For every `1` governance token minted via our staking contract to our community members, we emit an additional `0.5` governance tokens to `ubq.eth`

I think it could be a very interesting proof of concept for future DAOs to fund development automatically by emitting governance tokens to a wallet that is controlled by the UbiquiBot for their repositories. 

What would be the simplest way to add an additional split, but within the protocol level? 

To clarify, this is a low priority task that would be used primarily for selling a future vision (this is why I think it should be implemented on the smart contract level.)

It would be great if we can set multiple emission destinations and set the amounts. That way, for example, maintenance on this repository can receive 5% of all governance token emissions, UbiquiBot repository 10% etc. 

### Context

- Here is a recent [reward claim](https://etherscan.io/tx/0xb172ee408a0129d635b2ffd6f4ffd673573761956d6ae099a18ed1e22843554b).
- https://github.com/ubiquity/ubiquity-dollar/blob/7a70182d49a0b9dc947c9925a5d28edc49c28b0d/packages/contracts/src/dollar/libraries/LibChef.sol#L369-L372

We have the [UbiquityPoolFacet](https://github.com/ubiquity/ubiquity-dollar/blob/7a70182d49a0b9dc947c9925a5d28edc49c28b0d/packages/contracts/src/dollar/facets/UbiquityPoolFacet.sol) contract (which uses [LibUbiquityPool](https://github.com/ubiquity/ubiquity-dollar/blob/7a70182d49a0b9dc947c9925a5d28edc49c28b0d/packages/contracts/src/dollar/libraries/LibUbiquityPool.sol) library under the hood) which is responsible for minting/redeeming Dollar tokens for collateral.

Example:
1. User calls [mintDollar()](https://github.com/ubiquity/ubiquity-dollar/blob/7a70182d49a0b9dc947c9925a5d28edc49c28b0d/packages/contracts/src/dollar/facets/UbiquityPoolFacet.sol#L20) and sends 100 LUSD as collateral
2. User gets 100 Dollars

Now check this [test](https://github.com/rndquu/ubiquity-dollar/blob/5b6bcd03837b2f8cc704593534e9742f6cc5af75/packages/contracts/test/diamond/facets/UbiquityPoolFacet.t.sol#L345). It basically simulates the [calcMintDollarAmount()](https://github.com/ubiquity/ubiquity-dollar/blob/7a70182d49a0b9dc947c9925a5d28edc49c28b0d/packages/contracts/src/dollar/libraries/LibUbiquityPool.sol#L382) method responsible for calculating how much Dollars should be minted/redeemed in exchange for collateral tokens.

The calculation seems to be wrong because when we try to get the collateral price in USD here https://github.com/ubiquity/ubiquity-dollar/blob/7a70182d49a0b9dc947c9925a5d28edc49c28b0d/packages/contracts/src/dollar/libraries/LibUbiquityPool.sol#L438 we use cumulative price which seems to be wrong. As a result user gets much more Dollars in exchange for collateral. Example:
1. User calls [mintDollar()](https://github.com/ubiquity/ubiquity-dollar/blob/7a70182d49a0b9dc947c9925a5d28edc49c28b0d/packages/contracts/src/dollar/facets/UbiquityPoolFacet.sol#L20) and sends 100 LUSD as collateral
2. User gets `~239561778028138198.47` Dollars which is way too high

As a part of the current issue we should add a new method to the [oracle faucet](https://github.com/ubiquity/ubiquity-dollar/blob/7a70182d49a0b9dc947c9925a5d28edc49c28b0d/packages/contracts/src/dollar/facets/TWAPOracleDollar3poolFacet.sol) which will be responsible for fetching collateral token prices in USD.

Possible options:
1. Curve TWAP (we already use it for the Dollar token)
2. Chainlink oracles

### Overview

- To make a long story short, we had three farming (MasterChef/liquidity mining) contracts since the launch of the protocol. We had two wrappers called "Bonding" that allowed us to manipulate the liquidity, including for migrations in `Bonding v2`.
- `MasterChef v1` there was a bug discovered after a month or so of operation.
- `MasterChef v2` was a rushed fix as the bug was critical, which also ended up having a critical bug. This was only live for about two days.
- `MasterChef v2.1` is what we are using currently on mainnet and seems to be stable.
- The longer one's stake is locked up, the higher the multiplier. e.g. 1x for 1 year lockup; 4x for 4 year lockup. 
- However in one of the migrations (I believe only those who jumped into `v2` [which was only three of us](https://etherscan.io/address/0xb8ec70d24306ecef9d4aaf9986dcb1da5736a997/advanced#tokentxns)) the multiplier seems to have gotten wiped (my personal 4x seems to have been credited only 1x)
- Those who migrated from `MasterChef v1` to `MasterChef v2.1` seem to not have been affected.

### Objective

This bounty is to confirm where/how exactly the multiplier got wiped, verify that these are the only affected parties, and to draft a solution that will make the affected parties whole before they withdraw their stake sometime in 2024. 

The solution can be semi-manual as there only seem to be three affected parties. My expectation for the solution is: 1. that we can transfer UBQ to make them current (you should provide the math for this) and then 2. modify their existing bonding shares to include the 4x multiplier with instructions you provide by using the Etherscan writeContract interface.

I would scrutinize [MasterChef v2](https://etherscan.io/address/0xb8ec70d24306ecef9d4aaf9986dcb1da5736a997#code) the closest, because only those who seem to have interacted with it are affected (this is from my memory, I am not the expert at on-chain forensics) as well as [Bonding v2](https://etherscan.io/address/0xc251ecd9f1bd5230823f9a0f99a44a87ddd4ca38#code)  as this invoked the migration function. 

## Appendix

```
is the same as this one:
```typescript
const diamondAddress = '0xbe0efAbc83686a81903C1D4a2515f8111e53B5Cb';
const managerContract = await getUbiquityManagerContract(diamondAddress, provider);

###  Why Implement Docker to Enhance the Development Experience in Your Repository

Docker has become increasingly popular in the world of software development due to its ability to simplify the deployment and management of applications. Integrating Docker into your repository can significantly enhance the development experience for your team. Here are several compelling reasons why you should consider implementing Docker:

### 1. Consistent Development Environment
One of the challenges developers often face is setting up and configuring the development environment. With Docker, you can define the entire environment in a Dockerfile, ensuring that all team members have a consistent setup. This eliminates the common "works on my machine" problem and reduces the time spent troubleshooting environment-specific issues.

### 2. Reproducible Builds
Docker provides reproducibility for software builds. By encapsulating the dependencies and configuration within a container, you can ensure that the build process is consistent across different machines. This allows for easy sharing of the build artifacts and simplifies collaboration within the team.

### 3. Isolation and Dependency Management
Docker containers create isolated environments, allowing applications to run independently without interfering with the underlying host system. This isolation enables efficient management of dependencies, as you can package all the required libraries, frameworks, and tools within the container. Developers can work on multiple projects with different dependencies simultaneously, avoiding conflicts and versioning issues.

### 4. Scalability and Flexibility
Docker enables horizontal scalability by leveraging container orchestration tools like Kubernetes. With Docker, you can easily scale your applications up or down to meet varying workload demands. This flexibility is particularly beneficial for projects that require rapid scaling or handle significant traffic fluctuations.

### 5. Streamlined Onboarding and Continuous Integration
When new developers join the team, Docker simplifies the onboarding process. They can quickly spin up the development environment by running a single command to pull and run the Docker image. Additionally, integrating Docker into your continuous integration (CI) pipeline allows for seamless testing and deployment, ensuring consistent and reliable software delivery.

### 6. Portability and Compatibility
Docker containers are highly portable, meaning they can run on any platform that supports Docker. This portability eliminates the need to worry about differences in underlying operating systems or system configurations. Developers can easily switch between different environments, such as local development machines, staging servers, and production environments, without modifications.

### 7. Version Control of Infrastructure
By using Dockerfiles and Docker Compose files, you can version control the infrastructure and configurations required to run your application. This allows you to track changes, roll back to previous versions, and collaborate more effectively within your development team.

Implementing Docker in your repository offers numerous benefits that enhance the development experience. It provides consistency, reproducibility, isolation, scalability, and flexibility, streamlines onboarding and CI processes, ensures portability, and allows version control of the infrastructure. By embracing Docker, you empower your team to focus more on developing features and less on environment-related issues, leading to increased productivity and smoother collaboration.

`call()` should be used instead of `transfer()` to transfer ether.

## Summary
`call()` should be used instead of `transfer()` to transfer ether.

Plase view;
- https://www.theblock.co/post/225364/zksync-unfreeze-millions-stuck

## Vulnerability Detail
The `transfer()` and `send()` functions forward a fixed amount of 2300 gas. Historically, it has often been recommended to use these functions for value transfers to guard against reentrancy attacks. However, the gas cost of EVM instructions may change significantly during hard forks which may break already deployed contract systems that make fixed assumptions about gas costs. For example. EIP 1884 broke several existing smart contracts due to a cost increase of the SLOAD instruction.

## Impact
The use of the deprecated transfer() function for an address will inevitably make the transaction fail when:

- The claimer smart contract does not implement a payable function.
- The claimer smart contract does implement a payable fallback which uses more than 2300 gas unit.
- The claimer smart contract implements a payable fallback function that needs less than 2300 gas units but is called through proxy, raising the call's gas usage above 2300.
- Additionally, using higher than 2300 gas might be mandatory for some multisig wallets.

- [UbiquiStickSale.sol#L122](https://github.com/ubiquity/ubiquity-dollar/blob/development/packages/contracts/src/ubiquistick/UbiquiStickSale.sol#L122)

Low Security issue, Decrement storage slot hashes by one

## Description 
The storage slots/hashes have known pre-images. For example [LibCreditRedemptionCalculator.sol#L29-L30](https://github.com/ubiquity/ubiquity-dollar/blob/0c240d095cae6be599e020a8a6ba4d0a5fcf51c6/packages/contracts/src/dollar/libraries/LibCreditRedemptionCalculator.sol#L29-L30), [LibBondingCurve.sol#L19-L20](https://github.com/ubiquity/ubiquity-dollar/blob/0c240d095cae6be599e020a8a6ba4d0a5fcf51c6/packages/contracts/src/dollar/libraries/LibBondingCurve.sol#L19-L20), there are many others instances with the same issue.

## Recommendation
Quote from [EIP-1967](https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-1967)
> Furthermore, a -1 offset is added so the preimage of the hash cannot be known, further reducing the chances of a possible attack.

Current implementation is;
`bytes32 constant SLOT = keccak256("path.to.slot");`

Change it to:
`bytes32 constant SLOT = bytes32(uint256(keccak256("path.to.slot")) -1);`

Deep Fuzzing on Newly Modified Solidity Files

Random thought I had but since I [wrote that action](https://github.com/ubiquity/bounty-bot/blob/c1c6c99336f34ac5e94efaed49c9f218fb7a2d76/.github/workflows/push.yml#L36-L43) that will: 

1. read the bounty-bot repo and 
3. build if any source code changes occur, and then 
4. commit the built file to the repo 

It inspired me to think of what other compute we can delegate to the cloud to make the dev experience better. 

What if we do something similar with deep fuzzing, but only on modified Solidity files? I understand that deep fuzzing takes a lot of time, so we could run it for the entire codebase one time, and then only run it on modified Solidity files moving forward? I vaguely recall a discussion related to how deep fuzzing is super slow.

transmissions11 has a Foundry template that does a deep fuzz on everything when merged to main, which served as another point of inspiration for me.

```yml
      - name: Run tests
        run: forge test
        env:
          # Only fuzz intensely if we're running this action on a push to main or for a PR going into main:
          FOUNDRY_PROFILE: ${{ (github.ref == 'refs/heads/main' || github.base_ref == 'main') && 'intense' }}
```
https://github.com/transmissions11/foundry-template/blob/0bf8e53589f2e8f72e41baf672c25aa35ba57295/.github/workflows/tests.yml#L28-L32

Create a deploy script for protocol

## Problems
We have deploy scripts written in typescript + `forge create` but its just for individual smart contract. It is needed for us to have a script which will deploy everything to a target network in one command and configure everything needed.

Protocol deployment script can be like the followings
`yarn workspace @ubiquity/contracts run deploy:development` 
`yarn workspace @ubiquity/contracts run deploy:staging` 
`yarn workspace @ubiquity/contracts run deploy:production` 

Once the deploy script runs successfully, UI should be connected to the deployed addresses automatically and working properly.

Allow users to convert Ubiquity Dollars to Ubiquity Credits (fungible).

Depends on #115

## Background

uCR also needs a premium for burning uAD, otherwise, it makes no sense.
- [ ] requires `premium` variable 

uCR uses the same formula for premium as uCR-NFT, however it gets only 70% of the premium (configurable)
- [ ] requires `offset` variable 

The depreciation rate of uAD is defined in such a way, that at the time of uCR-NFT expiration, uCR is worth 70% (configurable via setting the rate - R) of its original value. 
- [ ] requires `rate` variable #115

## Math Overview

For example: if the expiration duration is 30 days, then we can define the needed rate  - R for the period as:

```
(1+R)^(blocks) = 1/0.7
```

If we assume 1 block per 12 seconds, in 30 days we get 216 000 blocks

Then: 

```
(1+R) ^216000 = 1.4286
R =  0.000001651366844
```

The ratio of uAD/uCR starts at 1 and we define an inflation rate (the one which we derived above, for example). Then the ratio of the uAD/AR changes with each block according to the formula:

```
(1+R)^(elapsed blocks)
```

Important: R should be configurable for a given period. E.g. we should be able to change R, without this affecting negatively already existing uCR. 

If we assume a block time of 12 seconds, this gives us the following ratio per day:

## Math Examples

So lets look at an example:
User A wants to burn 1000 uAD on day 1. The current ratio is 1:1 and we offer him 30% premium (for example). He gets 1000 * 1 * 1.3 = 1300 uCR
On day 15 debt cycle ends, the mint cycle begins
On day 16 the ratio is 1.19. If the user redeems his 1300 uCR at this point, he would get 1300/1.19 = 1092 uAD
On day 31 the ratio is 1.42. If the user redeems his 1300 uCR at this point, he would get 1300/1.42 = 915 uAD


Example2:
The debt cycle has started on day 5, at a ratio of 1.048 (irrelevant for further calculations, just here to show that the 1:1 ratio is a fixed point in time and not associated with cycles)
User B wants to burn 1000 uAD on day 10. The current ratio is 1:1.11 and we offer him a premium of (10%, since we are later in the debt cycle). He would then get: 1000 * 1.1 * 1.1 = 1210 uCR
On day 31, the debt cycle ends, we mint and the user redeems his funds at a ratio of  1.42. He would get back 1210 / 1.42 = 852 uAD

https://docs.google.com/document/d/12gGDjRw4s1TRH4mT9v3yb_TFnFDKfzKgTjTfIKtoAMM/edit

Allow users to convert Ubiquity Credit NFTs to Ubiquity Credits (fungible).

Depends on #115 (we need to know the redemption rate of `1 uCR` for `? uAD` as it has less redemption power over time)

## Background

- We know that uCR-NFT is always worth 1 uAD
- We know how much uAD is 1 uCR worth at any given point in time
  - Depends on #115
- We know what duration of the uCR-NFT remains in percentage

## Math
 
 ```
(1 uCR-NFT) * (Remaining duration %) * (uCR/uAD conversion rate)
```

> Example:
> 
> 10 000 uCR-NFT with a total duration of 6 months has been around for 4 months, so they have 33% duration remaining.
> uCR/uAD redemption rate is 1.5
> So the user can get: 10 000 * 33% * 1.5 = 4 950 uCR (which is currently worth 3300 uAD)

> Using the CreditClock we should consider the price of the uAD-uAD-equivalent of the uCR-NFT > amount (right now it converts 1-1) (this means dividing it by the CreditClock > creditRateAtBlockNumber, the result should be a higher amount of uCR (because it's devalued))
> At mint time the conversion should be 100%
> At expiration time the conversion should be 0%
> In between we lower it linearly using the expiration time
Create Archival Repository for deprecated V1 Contracts

In an effort to avoid confusion we have been removing deprecated contracts from the active repository as they're replaced. 
This has caused some issues when there's a need to reference these contracts for research or investigation purposes as we've had to go and then find them on Etherscan or elsewhere. 
I propose to create an archival repository for the V1 contracts as they were originally deployed. This will create a consistent reference point that can be installed as a library for any future needs. 
It is my recommendation that the same be done with the current production environment should it ever be replaced.

How to Handle Complex Breaking Merges for Other Bounty Hunters?

I did an interactive rebase and pushed to https://github.com/ubiquity/ubiquity-dollar/tree/devsupport-org/development

I think there were a lot of unnecessary commits and I suggest that you do experimentation/research on a branch off of your main branch when working on complex features. That way, if you make changes for exploratory reasons, and eventually revert, you can drop the branch and you don't add the unnecessary commits to your PR. Unnecessary commits can make merges (or in my case, rebasing) more complex than it needs to be. 

Unfortunately the CI from my interactive rebase seems far from working and I'm not sure of the best solution here other than starting on a clean branch. 

On one hand, we technically should have revoked the bounty after week 2 (this is a 1 week bounty) but it seemed like you were making good progress. On the other hand, if we can't figure out how to solve these sort of issues, I think that our decentralized development is going to struggle to scale. 

@0xcodercrane this is the exact type of problem I was seeking to avoid when I asked you to look into merging https://github.com/ubiquity/ubiquity-dollar/pull/351

I think we should have an all hands meeting with the other pro devs in our org to get their opinion on how to best solve this type of issue.

Sell Pressure Dampening via Transfer Hook - Proof of Concept

Let's say that a whale is selling huge amount of uAD on the curve metapool. This can very affect the peg and trigger an unwanted chain of events leading to a bank run. 
The idea is to use the transfer hook to detect and counter that sell with a one sided liquidity provision 
so the flow is 
use sells uAD from uAD-3crv metapool 
that triggers a hook that will transfer an ERC20 (e.g) to the metapool as a one sided liquidity 
the erc20 belongs to the hook contract and only the hook contract can provide it as liquidity and thus receive the corresponding LP token 

- POC to make sure it is safe and sound
- it should trigger is uAD sell is > `X Amount`
- it should provide `Y Amount` of `DAI` `USDC` `USDT` as liquity where  `Y = z * X`
- Nice-to-have accurate calculation of the price change due to the liquidity deposit  

estimation between 1 and 2 days

Upgrade TWAP to poll data based on a controller

The twap price we will target is an aggregation of various data sources grouped depending on their gas cost and origin, current groups are ChainLink price feeds Uma optimistic oracles Median aggregation of dexes Web3 api These data sources will be called based on market conditions. When there is not a lot of volume amount of transactions is minimum and volatility is low only the cheapest price feeds will be called, as the conditions change to a harsher, more lively market data sources will progressively be added until the twap becomes an aggregation of all possible data sources This has the purpose of making our oracle calls as efficient as possible by reducing the gas used determining the twap by reducing our set of data sources in safer market conditions while at the same time being able to ramp the robustness during higher volatility periods These calls will be determined by a proportional controller (this ideally will evolve into full PID in future versions) based on Volume per unit of time (daily, hourly or block based) Amount of tx per unit of time (daily, hourly or block based) The controller will work based on 3 variables, a simplified version of them is 1. Volume and tx aggregation (V), as the process variable 2. Oracle base polls (BP), as the set variable. which has 2 elements P is the actual amount of polls per unit of time B is a baseline variable, its a function that will increase or decrease overtime to change the net polls done and is affected by the third variable generated at the output, it's the feedback element of the system 3. Poll rate(R), the output variable. is the result of the V-BP proportion, it will increase P variable (the actual amount of polls) as well as the delta of B The resulting equations will be then V-BP=R, since the controller always wants to be at 0 and V is what where measuring then; R=BP, as B is an independent function of time only P can be changed as a result of an R change In this simplified example when volume rises the difference between the base polls (BP) and volume (V) increases causing the poll rate (R) to increase, since the controller always wants to be at 0 the net polls (P) increase As the difference goes back to 0 due to base polls increasing in tandem with volume the baseline (B) increases as an effect of the R increase allowing the net polls go down while the baseline stays the same, as this new volume is deemed new normal When volume decreases P has to go down to bring the difference back to 0, as R is a negative number. This negative R causes B to also go down over time, increasing the net polls after given amount of time Baseline function This will change what the controller defines as normal volume , a simple way to see it is in an unit of time the controller wants it to be the equal to R By example it should go from 1 to 3 in a week Contract structure The current contract structure is based on the way I design electronics, this means it will probably be shit in some aspects, for a more exact spec look at RAI controller contracts an individual contract for each individual data source, in this version that means 4 Individual interfaces to normalize the data sources to a common format for the controller to read, another 4 A controller contract This puts the total to 9 in this current iteration

In order to keep development workflow clean and without delays, commits should be fairly thin in terms of checks. Devs should be capable of rebasing their own branch locally if they need to fix anything before pushing, which can reject after many larger checks of the codebase such as spell check and lints. It may also be worthwhile to consider dropping prettier altogether, given that it is basically doing the same job as eslint. I would propose the following checklist, not necessarily in this order.

- [x] drop prettier
- [ ] shift to pre-push rather than commit
- [x] utilize workspaces
- [ ] fix [cross package ignore requirements](https://github.com/ubiquity/ubiquity-dollar/pull/318/files#diff-e7e195d3d8fa5b82fa51ed952f3a179d429cbc46c0432ce1f7b357c54c162822R6) by scoping linting appropriately
- [x] possible to utilize npm packages instead of lib folders?

# Features of Interest

## Ubiquity Credit (uCR) Cashback Rewards Program
1. Rewards program to incentivize usage
2. We should be earning like 1-2% on purchases directly afaik, 
    1. Meaning we can take this money to back the dollar (meaning uCR should become more liquid)
3. We could model it off of Starbucks' wildly successful rewards program and even simulate "expiring stars" with uCR-NFT

## Automatic loans via Liquity/MakerDAO
1. Covers small and short term liquidity crunches for when you're out and don't want to rehypothecate funds on chain to buy something    
2. You stake $1000 in some liquid Ubiquity asset (uAD, UBQ)        
    1. Curious to know if we should put it in a vault to make yield, or if staking uAD is good enough.
3. You deposit $1000 into your Ubiquity checking account (uAD, and maybe USDC/DAI/USDT)
4. Our protocol automatically opens up a Trove/CDP for you using Ubiquity owned ETH (or maybe have a global Trove/CDP, but seems riskier)
5. You spend $1000 on your UbiquiCard and your checking account balance is $0.
6. You need to spend another $500 on your UbiquiCard, and your position is backed by the Trove/CDP ($500 of DAI/LUSD is minted and covers your debt automatically)
    1. In theory, we could also instantly mint uCR and dump it to cover the user's debt; and liquidate the user's stake on our own terms instead of when the Trove/CDP demands a liquidation. But it feels like a bad idea to directly mess with stabilization mechanics (minting/burning)
7. You receive a warning and maybe a small "overdraft fee" which covers the gas costs for minting the LUSD    
    1. Need to think more about what happens if ETH goes down and these Troves/CDPs get liquidated. 
    2. We might be able to back a hedge, where we spot hold ETH in the Trove/CDP on behalf of the customer, and open a short position on DYDX to cover market moves. But this will increase borrowing costs...
        1. funding rate - in the last week I've seen spikes up to 18% APR funding rate, so with a 10% extra liquidation buffer that should cover short term loans.
    4. An obvious adjustment would be that we add another 10% buffer for liquidations (instead of 90% from Liquity, going through us we allow 80% utilization)
## Privacy.com-style Virtual Card Generation 
1. To control finances better (might also be able to just use Privacy.com)

## MetaVault Savings Account 
1. Cycle between our whitelisted, and highest APR vaults to get a savings account that nets 10-20% APR on stables

TWAP Oracle needs to determine peg (track $1.00 USD accurately)

This needs more research but currently our TWAP oracle tracks 3crv, which currently is trading ~$1.02. The net effect of this is that our dollar thinks that our peg is ~$1.02 (1:1 match)

The `consult` method in the oracle contract needs to be updated to actually track $1.00. Off hand and without research, there's several approaches we can take for this: 
1. We can based off of ether's price (chainlink oracles?) 
2. We can off of another stablecoin (centralized is bad, and DAI might do a freefloating peg)
3. Some more complex math perhaps grabbing some sort of average of the underlying assets in 3crv
4. Check all the curve/uniswap pools on chain and grab the median price of stablecoin pairs. I'm betting that most pairs on curve are dollar pegged so this could work. Best if we can do this without gas (reading from the chain should be free)

The method lives here:

https://github.com/ubiquity/ubiquity-dollar/blob/enhancement/styles/packages/contracts/dollar/contracts/TWAPOracle.sol#L70-L81

> Also worth noting but 3pool is starting to deviate quite a bit from $1.00 due to the UST bank run (it accrues swap fees in the 3pool) we're going to need to account for this in our core contracts  https://www.coingecko.com/en/coins/lp-3pool-curve

## Overview
### Objective
- The purpose of this smart contract is to allow talent to convert their cash (intended for base payroll) into uCR and/or UBQ.

### Benefits
- We can incentivize talent to leave cash equivalents (e.g. USDC/DAI) with us to reduce our burn rate.
- We can skip negotiating the `uCR`/`UBQ` compensation with talent during the hiring process and have them handle it permissionlessly via this contract.

## Specification

The contract should...

- be pausable.
- be manually topped up with UBQ and uCR for security reasons.
- have a token acceptance whitelist (we can start with USDC, DAI, LUSD)
- have a risk premium getter/setter for UBQ
- - this should be defined as a separate smart contract to allow for algorithmic risk premium
- have a risk premium getter/setter for uCR
- - this should be defined as a separate smart contract to allow for algorithmic risk premium
- automatically transfers to the Ubiquity Treasury

### Draft Contact Methods

```solidity
setTreasuryAddress(address treasuryCalculator) onlyTreasury // treasuryCalculator should query the [manager contract](https://etherscan.io/address/0x4DA97a8b831C345dBe6d16FF7432DF2b7b776d98) for the address of the treasury
getTreasuryAddress() returns (address)

setGovernanceTokenAddress(address tokenAddress) onlyTreasury
setGovernanceTokenRiskPremium(address riskPremiumCalculator) onlyTreasury
getGovernanceTokenRiskPremium() returns (uint256)

setCreditTokenAddress(address tokenAddress) onlyTreasury
setCreditTokenRiskPremium(address riskPremiumCalculator) onlyTreasury
getCreditTokenRiskPremium() returns (uint256)

depositForGovernanceTokens(uint256 amount) pauseable // transfers UBQ to caller; transfers deposit to treasury.
depositForCreditTokens(uint256 amount) pauseable // transfers uCR to caller; transfers deposit to treasury.

freeze() onlyTreasury // pauses all
```

## Context

I was thinking we could assign an economy wide "risk premium" for uCR. This can represent the rate we pay it out. e.g. 

"2" means `2 uCR` = `1 USDC`
"1.5" means `1.5 uCR` = `1 USDC`

(This also can apply for UBQ.)

- I think it makes sense to think in these terms because now that it is a full blown bear market, perhaps the risk premium should be something higher, like "5"

- Would be amazing to set at the smart contract level, that way the talent we pay out can decide on their own how much they want to gamble. They could, for example, be always paid the base rate of USDC/DAI, but then have the ability to deposit into the smart contract to mint uCR. If the risk premium is 5, then $1000 of USDC will mint 5000 uCR.

- This way we no longer have to negotiate this, as the worker can decide how much risk they want on the fly.

- Theoretically we could do the same for UBQ.

### Algorithmic Risk Premium (UBQ)

Another interesting idea is to algorithmically define the risk premium by calculating ETH price from the peak. 
If ETH peak price was the following according to [CoinGecko](https://www.coingecko.com/en/coins/ethereum):

All-Time High
`$4,878.26`-76.0%
Nov 10, 2021 (7 months)

Ethereum Price
`$1,168.76`

`4878.26 / 1168.76 = 4.1738765872`

Risk premium could be `4.1738765872` for `UBQ`. 

I think the risk premium for alts should be a function of the entire market. I also think that UBQ risk premium should consider the UBQ market price (Uniswap etc) although this is more exploitable due to its smaller liquidity compared to ETH

### Algorithmic Risk Premium (uCR)

This should be a function of the TWAP and consider how often we go above peg. 

- The idea is that if we're constantly above peg, and uCR is redeemable most of the time; a reasonable person should conclude that the risk (and its associated premium) should be lower for holding uCR.
- If we're in a situation like we have been, where its been a long time since uCR has been redeemable, then its risk premium should go much higher!

Introducting Ubiquity Credit Cashback Program, similar to credit cards! + #158 + #165 + #166 ## Overview > .eth | U B I Q U I T Y: i came up with a hack to make the opensea thing work > .eth | U B I Q U I T Y: > > .eth | U B I Q U I T Y: so basically we modify our linkedin chrome extension (already has great infra, client side!) to modify the opensea ui > .eth | U B I Q U I T Y: then we deploy one or two contracts to middle man the transaction > .eth | U B I Q U I T Y: in these contracts, we take, for example, a 2.5% fee (just like a credit card/payment processor company) and then give them cashback; for example up to 10% in Ubiquity Credits (uCR) or the total of all sum fees (e.g. 2.5% OpenSea, 5% creator fee, 2.5% our processing fee) > .eth | U B I Q U I T Y: this gives us a new revenue source > .eth | U B I Q U I T Y: behind the scenes, we swap the ubiquity dollar for eth/weth used for the purchase and complete the opensea transaction > T Flex : i wouldnt replace the button but add another one ## Smart Contract The purpose of the "middle-man" contract would be to perform the following: 1. receive the user's uAD 1. set aside uCR valued at 10% of this uAD amount 1. for security reasons, we should top up this contract manually with uCR 1. check now for the NFT price, and what asset the NFT is priced in (WETH, ETH, DAI, USDC?) and if the uAD amount is valued at 102.5% of the NFT price, not including slippage on the uAD swap. 1. we should automatically handle choosing and swapping for the correct purchase asset as an extra convenience for the user 1. swap for ETH using the user's uAD (this should be valued at 102.5%+ of the NFT price) 1. purchase NFT with 97.5%, and keep 2.5% of the purchase amount, in the swapped for asset, e.g. ETH 1. send back NFT + uCR "cashback" to user ### Setters We should be able to set the following variables 1. transaction fee (default at 2.5%) 1. cashback percentage (default at 10%) 1. account for slippage (default true) ## Remarks This gives us a reason to do a bond for uAD-ETH and grow its liquidity.

Originally posted by **pavlovcik** May 14, 2022 # "Bring Your Own Yield Source" For the next iteration of the Proxy Yield Aggregator (PYA) program a user should be able to bring their own [ERC4626](https://github.com/fei-protocol/ERC4626/blob/7a947f2507b760ae470578cfb106f71ff5b1a14b/src/ERC4626Router.sol) compatible yield source, and connect it to our deposit contract. This product is intended for users to be able to stack the total yield that they can receive from their favorite yield bearing sources. Upon withdrawal, the user interface should present a slider which represents risk tolerance of the user. ## Example 1. The user likes a new ERC4626 Compatible Yearn USDC vault that promises 20% APR. 1. The user "connects" the ERC4626 vault to our deposit contract. 1. Implementation details must be researched, but I hope that we can avoid a contract redeployment, a la deploying a new Uniswap market. 1. The user deposits 1000 USDC, and the USDC is immediately transferred to the underlying yield source. 1. One year later, the user seeks to withdraw their 1200 USDC, and returns to our user interface to withdraw. 1. The user interface presents a slider, which seeks to understand the user's risk/reward tolerance 1. For example, the user can withdraw with no additional risk (1200 USDC) or the user can withdraw with max risk (2400 uCR) 1. The idea is that the user can convert the USDC into our uCR for a premium 1. In exchange, the Ubiquity Dollar is able to raise collateral for the dollar in perpetuity. 1. User withdraws at "25% r/r" netting them something like 900 USDC and 900 uCR (premium curve formula to be determined) 1. "50% r/r" would be 600 USDC and 1200 uCR 1. "100% r/r" is 0 USDC and 2400 uCR 1. "16.7% r/r" is 1000 USDC and 400 uCR // I imagine that many would, in this example go here or lower in order to only convert yield, and to receive the principle back. ## Adjustable Parameters 1. uCR Premium, a math formula (default would be a linear calculation, 1 USDC -> 2 uCR) 1. This would be deployed as a separate smart contract 1. This gives us flexibility to implement exponential or logarithmic functions which may more efficiently produce our desired economic outcomes! 1. Yield token whitelist (default would be an array with the following contract addresses: USDC, DAI, LUSD) 1. The idea is that, because the user is able to bring their own yield source, we wouldn't want a situation where they give assets that we do not want (like UST) 1. Rejection should happen upon deposit, not withdrawal; in case we change our accepted assets after the user already has deposited their tokens. ## Remarks It would be very interesting to match the uCR Premium (math formula) with the bond of the associated asset. That way we are purchasing at the same price premiums ecosystem wide. As long as we're mindful of 1. the interface implementation, and 2. that we architect it so we can associate the uCR Premium PER asset, then I think we can easily share the same formula between our bonds and the PYA.

Vercel fails to build when deploying. When we refactored everything into a monorepo we also significantly automated the build process. Unfortunately this new build process does not seem to work for Vercel.

* Please login to the @ubiquity-vercel account, then login to Vercel in order to access our staging environment.
* Vercel is programmed to run `yarn run vercel-build` automatically; so I hooked in a debugging script for this task `./build-scripts/vercel-build.sh`

* I suggest you debug the build process by editing this shell script, and directly pushing to the `@ubiquity-vercel/ubiquity-dollar-staging` repository.

# Multi asset withdrawal

I think we should leave open to the user to be able to determine the withdrawal asset (USDC, uAR, or a combination) upon withdrawal for enhanced UX. We can have a slider on the UI. Also, of course, the max USDC the user will be able to withdraw is the amount they farmed with their principle. 

Identical scenario with three different users with different risk tolerances:

### Risk on user
- User deposits 100 000 USDC @ 20% APY
- User waits a year.
- User decides to withdraw 100 000 USDC + 40 000 uAR

### Risk off user
- User deposits 100 000 USDC @ 20% APY
- User waits a year.
- User decides to withdraw 100 000 USDC + 20 000 USDC

### Risk average user
- User deposits 100 000 USDC @ 20% APY
- User waits a year.
- User decides to withdraw 100 000 USDC + 5 000 USDC + 12 500 uAR (The formula for this ratio should be figured out @hpiyankov)

[CONTRACTS] - DebtCouponManager V2 - Migrate corresponding uAR to uBOND

Currently investors and contributors were given uAR tokens as a sort of debt. The intention was not for these to deprecate in value. Since we're adding value deprecation to uAR, we need to convert the existing uAR that were given with this intention to  the newly created uBOND token that can be exchanged 1-1 with uAD when TWAP > 1 and has priority over uAR.

# What needs to happen

- Make a list of all addresses that hold uAR distributed with this intention
- Make an admin transaction to migrate them to uBOND

It's just a regular ERC20 token that can be redeemed 1-1 to uAD when the TWAP is > 1

# What needs to happen

- Create uBOND token
- Make redeeming function for uAD 1-1 when TWAP > 1
[CONTRACTS] - DebtCouponManager V2 - Add uBOND to debt redeeming priority

Right now while redeeming debts, uAR has priority over uDEBT.

During uDEBT redemption at `redeemCoupons` we make the following check:

```sol
require(
            autoRedeemToken.totalSupply() <= uAD.balanceOf(address(this)),
            "There aren't enough uAD to redeem currently"
        );
uint256 maxRedeemableCoupons = uAD.balanceOf(address(this)) -
            autoRedeemToken.totalSupply();
```

That should change to also sum the uBondToken total supply.

After adding the uBOND token we should instead check for the balance of the sum of both  uAR and uBOND instead.

And on the `burnAutoRedeemTokensForDollars` we should add something like:

```sol
require(
            uBondToken.totalSupply() <= uAD.balanceOf(address(this)),
            "There aren't enough uAD to redeem currently"
        );
uint256 maxRedeemableTokens = uAD.balanceOf(address(this)) -
            uBondToken.totalSupply();
```

## What needs to happen

- uBOND should be prioritized over uAR and uDEBT
- uAR should be prioritized over uDEBT
- uDEBT should be last
- Remember to convert the autoRedeemToken `totalSupply` to uAD by multiplying it by the DebtClock `rateAtBlockNumber`
[CONTRACTS] - DebtCouponManager V2 - Update uAR-uAD minting and burning with the DebtClock

Right now uAR is burned 1-1 with uAD when TWAP > 1; and minted 1-1 for uAD when TWAP < 1

## What should happen

- Divide the uAD burned for uAR by the DebtClock `uarRateAtBlockNumber`
- Multiply the uAR burned for uAD by the DebtClock `uarRateAtBlockNumber`
[CONTRACTS] - DebtCouponManager V2 - uAR to uDEBT conversion mechanism

Right now there is not way to convert uAR to uDEBT

## What needs to happen

- We need a function (maybe `burnAutoRedemptionForCoupons` for the sake of consistency) that takes any amount of uAR and mints the equivalent of uDEBT as if was being redeemed right there for uAD; so considering the DebtCoupon. To do this, we multiply it by the DebtClock `uarRateAtBlockNumber`
[CONTRACTS] - DebtCouponManager V2 - New uDEBT to uAR conversion mechanism

Right now if you convert uCR-NFT to uCR with the CreditManager you get a 1-1 conversion, no mater how close the uCR-NFT token is to expiring. While if expired does not allow you to convert at all.

The relevant function is `burnCreditNftsForCredits`

## What needs to happen

- Using the CreditClock we should consider the price of the uAD-uAD-equivalent of the uCR-NFT amount (right now it converts 1-1) (this means dividing it by the CreditClock `creditRateAtBlockNumber`, the result should be a higher amount of uCR (because it's devalued))
- At mint time the conversion should be 100%
- At expiration time the conversion should be 0%
- In between we lower it linearly using the expiration time

Right now the DebtCouponManager works with uAR but without taking into consideration the DebtClock

## Current features

- Mints claimable dollars to get the price back to 1
- Exchange uAD for uAR 1-1 + premium when TWAP < 1
	-  Premium is calculated by UARForDollarsCalculator
- Exhange uAD for uDEBT + premium when TWAP < 1
	- Premium is calculated by CouponsForDollarsCalculator
- Exchange uAR for uAD 1-1 when TWAP > 1
- Exchange uDEBT for uAD 1-1 when TWAP > 1 and there are more uAD available than uAR
- Exchange expired uDEBT for UBQ at a configurable rate
- Exchange un-expired uDEBT for uAR at same value

## Considerations

At the moment will redeem your uAR fo uAD at 1-1; so if we implement the ubiquity/ubiquity-dollar-development#115  contract and for the [[Proxy Yield Aggregator, we'll need to re-deploy this one to also use it. However, while we keep the inflation at 0% nothing will change. This way we can deploy the YieldProxy contract with the DebtClock while keeping inflation at 0%, and when we also deploy the new DebtCouponManager we can start increasing the rate. Otherwise there is an opportunity to exploit the rate difference between the DebtCouponManager and the YieldProxy. (YieldProxy would give you more uAR to account for inflation, and the DebtCouponManager would redeem them 1-1 instead of inflation-adjusted)

We need a new contract that helps us calculate the uAR deprecation rate.

Details about the math available on [\[0094-UBQY\] uAR simple calc](https://docs.google.com/document/d/12gGDjRw4s1TRH4mT9v3yb_TFnFDKfzKgTjTfIKtoAMM/edit)

### Policy

The R value is determined by policy and the latest policy is that `The depreciation rate of uAD is defined in such a way, that at the time of uDEBT expiration, UAR is worth 70%`

The formula to get R is the following:

`(1+R)^(blockCountIn30Days) = 1/valueAfter30Days`
`R = (1/valueAfter30Days)^(1/blockCountIn30Days)-1`

So let's say we have 194.404 blocks in 30 days. And our valueAfter30Days is 0.7 (70%):

`(1+R)^(194404) = 1/0.7`
`R = (1/0.7)^(1/194404)-1 = 0.000001835`

But we don't need to know this for the contract, we just get the R value directly.


### Context

So the initial spec of the DebtClock called for a rate that can be updated multiple times. It called for storing the block the rate is updated and the rate itself; this way we can calculate the price of uAR for any block.

However, Ben mentioned that over time, as we update the rate and the array keeps getting longer, this can cause issues with the maximum gas fees. To prevent this we'll be removing the possibility to calculate the uAR price for any block, we will only be able to get the price for any block onward since the rate was last changed; older rates won't be stored.

### Customizable Variables

**.ratePerBlock**

This is the deprecatio rate. How much uAD is deprecated on each block.

Ex: 0.05 = 5% deprecation per block

**.rateStartBlock**

This is the block height from where we start applying the rate. Before this start block we won't have price information.

**.rateStartValue**

This is the exchange rate of uAR for the start block.

### Methods

**.setRatePerBlock(ratePerBlock)**

- Should set the `ratePerBlock`
- Should set the `rateStartValue` to the current rate value before it's changed
- Should set `rateStartBlock` to the current block height
- Should be only callable by admin

**.rate(blockNumber)**

- Should return the amount of uAR you would get for 1 uAD at the specific block number.
- If blockNumber isn't given then use the current block number.
- Require that blockNumber is less than **`rateStartBlock`**

### Rate math

```tsx
rateStartValue * ( 1 / ( (1 + ratePerBlock) ^ (blockNumber - rateStartBlock) ) )
```




## To be used on:

- DebtCouponManager: Adjust the uAR minting and burning to the rate
- YieldProxy: Adjust the uAR reward minting to the rate

[CONTRACTS] - Reviving uAD on swap rewards in UBQ

@zgorizzo69 do you think its realistic to automatically add/subtract from your current pending bonding rewards?

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4975670/134466329-98cd78f3-0cb7-4a6b-bf1f-a55c9d0bc34c.png)

### Example

You buy uAD when price below $1.00 and you get a small boost to your pending bonding rewards (more UBQ is withdraw-able) and if you sell immediately afterwards, then we slash some of your pending bonding rewards? This way we can "undo" somebody's reward if they undo the help to the system.

### Exploit Vector

User buys uAD below $1.00, withdraws pending UBQ rewards, then dumps uAD while its still below $1.00. IF we can go negative in the pending emissions then we're covered, assuming that we can not go negative then this is an exploit vector. 

Thoughts? @hpiyankov @zgorizzo69

Ubiquity's algorithmic dollar is not epoch-based, but is built around arbitrarily long or short debt cycles which adaptively modify the stabilization algorithms at play. Currently, the length of debt cycles depends on the TWAP crossing $1, whether decreasing or increasing in price. Because of this, the debt cycle can - in theory - never actually complete, or continue for an arbitrarily long enough time that would ultimately lead to destabilizing downstream effects on the protocol.

Although the epoch-less nature of the protocol offers many potential upsides with respect to adaptively dynamic algorithms acting on an effectively 'continuous' basis. However, the fact that debt cycles are arbitrarily long entails potential stability issues with respect to the debt algorithms that requires the debt cycles to end in order to trigger.

A design for a debt cycle timeout condition should be identified and implemented which would both rectify this potential stability vulnerability, while also respecting the epoch-less and continuous nature of Ubiquity's protocol.
[CONTRACTS] - Integrate or Create Keepers/Oracle Service to Replace Static blockCountInAWeek Estimate for Bonding Durations

Currently, bonding deposit times are being estimated using a static value:
`uint256 public blockCountInAWeek = 45361;`
See: https://github.com/ubiquity/uad-contracts/blob/main/contracts/Bonding.sol#L27

While unlikely, the value associated with the number of blocks verified over the period of one week can be subject to sudden change, and will at the least entail some small degree of drift over time. 

Once the DAO's governance rollout is complete, the time needed to make decisions to change code to the protocol's smart contracts may increase, creating a potential vulnerability in the protocol in cases of extreme discontinuous change in the rate blocks are being verified. 

A Keeper or similar oracle service, whether integrated externally or implemented by us, would allow us to update the contract with accurate and reliable external-time based triggers or notifications, side-stepping the issue of having to estimate the block verification rate and modify its hard-coded constant value via governance voting.
